LOAN, PROJECT, AND INVESTMENT SUMMARY
Borrower Independent State of Samoa
Project Description The Project is designed to generate additional income
and employment opportunities within the micro- and small
enterprise  (MSE)  sector  for  all  Samoans,  with  an
emphasis  on  those  in  rural  areas.  The  Project  will  (i)
support  the  expansion  of  the  small  business  loans
guarantee  scheme  (SBLGS)  utilizing  the  existing
management  framework  that  exists  through  the  Small
Business Enterprise Centre (SBEC); (ii) support a pilot
microfinance  facility  onlent  through  the  Development
Bank  of  Samoa  (DBS)  to  approved  participating
organizations;  (iii)  establish  a  Small  Business
Development  Fund  (SBDF)  to  purchase  additional
business advisory and training services from approved
business development service (BDS) providers; and (iv)
support the Government’s ongoing efforts to improve the
legal and regulatory environment for the corporate sector
generally,  in  particular  in  those  areas  that  impact  the
MSE sector. In addition, as part of the Project, the Asian
Development  Bank  (ADB)  will  consider  making  an
investment in a venture capital facility targeting MSE.
Classification Economic Growth
Environmental Assessment Category C. Environmental implications were reviewed,
and no significant adverse environmental impacts were
identified.
Rationale Over 80 percent of all businesses in Samoa have five or
fewer employees. Most of these enterprises do not have
adequate skill levels to create, manage, and increase the
size of their enterprises. These enterprises lack equity
and access to bank borrowings to provide a sustainable
financing basis for their development. With at least 80
percent of land under customary communal ownership,
which cannot be alienated either by sale or mortgage,
most  business  enterprises  have  limited  choices  of
acceptable  securities  that  they  can  offer  to  access
financial  services.  The  limited  freehold  land  that  is
available for securing borrowings from commercial banks
is concentrated around the Apia urban area. Therefore
the  problem  of  access  to  financial  services  is
compounded  for  rural  and  Savai'i-based  business
enterprises. Use of alternative securities for freehold land
has  been  limited.  Although  chattels  were  used
extensively for security,  the  commercial banks no longer

place reliance on such security because of enforceability
problems and the state of the relevant registries.
Since 1996, the Government has embarked on a process
of economic reform and liberalization, which recognizes
the private sector as the engine of growth. The reform
process has resulted in an environment that is conducive
to economic growth.
The Government's statements of economic strategy have
consistently  reinforced  the  partnership  between  the
private sector and Government. After focusing on major
macroeconomic  reforms,  the  Government  is  now
developing strategies to broaden the spread of benefits of
economic  growth.  ADB  has  supported  these  efforts
through Financial Sector Program loan. A key component
of these strategies is the development of infrastructure of
the  village  economy,  which  centers  around  MSEs.
Improving MSEs access to credit, supported by improved
access  to  services  provided  by  business  development
service providers, will contribute to growth in employment
and  income  earning  opportunities  in  this  sector.  The
Project reflects the ADB poverty reduction strategy.
Objectives and Scope The Project's goal is to generate income and employment
opportunities by expanding the MSE sector by improving
access  of  MSEs  to  credit,  and  business  training  and
advisory services. The Project has four components: (i)
expand the small business loans guarantee scheme, (ii)
support a pilot microfinance facility, (iii) enhance business
advisory and training services, and (iv) improve the policy
and  legislative  environment  for  small  business
development.
Cost Estimates The total cost of the Project is estimated at $4.5 million
equivalent including taxes and contingencies.
Financing Plan ADB loan financing is proposed at $3.5 million equivalent
(78 percent of the total costs). Government financing will
amount to $1.0 million equivalent (22 percent).
Loan Amount and Terms The equivalent in various currencies of Special Drawing
Rights 2,697,000 ($3.5 million) from ADB’s Special Funds
resources, with a maturity of 32 years, including a grace
period of 8 years, and an interest charge of 1.0 percent
per annum during the grace period and 1.5 percent per
annum thereafter, to be paid semiannually.
Equity Investment ADB will subscribe up to the equivalent of 25 percent of
issued and paid-up capital in a Samoan venture capital
fund (VCF). ADB’s investment will be up to $400,000.

The overall size of the VCF is proposed at $1.6 million.
Other  primary  shareholders  are  likely  to  be  the
International Finance Corporation (IFC), the Australia and
New  Zealand  Banking  Group  Ltd,  DBS,  and  Samoa
National Provident Fund. The target market for the VCF
will be venture capital investments of up to $100,000.
Project size is expected to range from roughly $67,000 to
$400,000  equivalent,  with  a  majority  being  expansion
projects. The life of the VCF is proposed at 10 years. Exit
options  for  the  VCF  will  be  existing  shareholders  of
investee companies. Commercial financiers will provide
take-up  when  the  specific  business  matures  and
becomes bankable under conventional criteria.
Period of Utilization Until 30 June 2006.
Executing Agency Treasury Department
Implementation Arrangements The  Treasury  Department  will  constitute  a  project
steering  committee  (PSC)  at  project  start-up,  with  the
secretary of finance as the chair. The PSC will establish a
subcommittee  to  manage  the  SBDF.  The  PSC  will
establish  a  project  management  unit  (PMU),  with  a
manager recruited from the private sector. DBS will be
the Implementing Agency (IA) for the onlending of the
pilot microfinance component. The Women in Business
Foundation  (WIBF)  will  be  the  initial  participating
organization for the microfinance component. SBEC will
be the IA for the SBLGS component. Business training,
monitoring, and advisory services  components  to  be
funded under the SBDF will be awarded to accredited
participating  organizations  (initially  identified  as  SBEC
and WIBF), based on medium-term work plans submitted
by  the  participating  organizations,  and  approved  for
funding from the SBDF.
Procurement All  procurement  under  the  Project  will  follow  ADB’s
Guidelines for Procurement. The PMU will be responsible
for all procurement. Vehicles, computers, and other office
equipment  will  be  procured  subject  to  international
shopping procedures or direct purchase, depending on
the contract amounts involved.
Consulting Services A PMU manager will be engaged for the duration of the
Project.  Furthermore,  a  systems  specialist  will  be
engaged  for  6  person-months.  A  small  business
development expert will be engaged for up to 5 person-
months, and auditors on an annual basis. Furthermore,
Legal experts may be engaged as required to facilitate
drafting  of  various  agreements  under  the  Project.  All
consultants to be financed out of the loan proceeds will

be engaged in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the
Use of Consultants and other arrangements satisfactory
to ADB.
Estimated Project Completion 28 February 2006.
Date
Benefits and Beneficiaries The Project will contribute to poverty reduction through
improving  access  of  micro-  and  small  enterprises  to
credit,  and  business  development  services,  thus
facilitating income-generating activities. It is expected that
during  the  five  years  of  project  implementation,  the
Project  will  directly  create  an  additional  1,400  direct
income and employment opportunities, benefiting at least
5,600 people.
The specified target group for this Project includes rural
households with residences outside of urban Apia, and
no direct income stream from paid employment in Apia.
There are no specific poverty areas or geographic areas
that would require priority support. The most important
target groups in this Project are small entrepreneurs, both
male and female, that would like to expand or consolidate
existing  businesses  and  require  additional  financial
resources for this purpose.
The Project will facilitate diversification of the financial
sector  in  Samoa,  logically  extending  policy  dialogue
initiated  under  the  Financial  Sector  Program.  Also,  by
improving the legal and regulatory environment pertaining
to  entrepreneurship  development,  the  Project  will
facilitate private sector-led economic growth.
Risks Risk areas for the Project include continuing adherence
of the Government to public sector reforms and private
sector development in the aftermath of the parliamentary
elections  scheduled  for  the  first  half  of  2001.  More
specifically, issues related to customary land reforms may
prove to be sensitive. Also, while current macroeconomic
conditions are quite stable, underpinned by robust private
sector  growth  and  continuing  strong  remittances  from
abroad, these conditions may deteriorate, either because
of the slower growth in exports, due to market changes,
or  decline  in  remittances.  Samoa  will  always  be
vulnerable to natural disasters similar to the devastation
caused by the two major cyclones in 1990 and 1991, and
the adverse impact of taro leaf blight disease in 1992-94.
Further risks could arise from the weak demand for the
SBEC  credit  guarantee  scheme,  slow  take  up  of
investments by the VCF, and unforeseen weakening of IA

institutional capacities. An additional risk is that VCF will
not materialize despite all the preparatory work.
These risks are considered acceptable due to the recent
record  of  the  SBEC  credit  guarantee  scheme,  and
demand  assessments  conducted  during  the  VCF
feasibility study. Risks related to the VCF will be mitigated
by the fact that any actual investment of ADB in the VCF
is  contingent  on  IFC  participation,  as  a  lead  investor.
Also, continuing strong growth of Samoa's economy will
underpin  demand.  The  Project  will  include  mitigating
measures  directed  at  institutional  strengthening  of  the
IAs.
Technical Assistance ADB will provide technical assistance (TA) for Capacity
Building  of  Financial  and  Business  Advisory
Intermediaries.  The  TA  will  support  (i)  policy  and
legislative  reviews;  (ii)  institutional  strengthening  of
SBEC, DBS, WIBF, and other participating institutions;
and (iii) the setting up an upgraded chattels registry and a
new  credit  reference  scheme.  Consultants  will  be
recruited  in  accordance  with  ADB’s Guidelines on the
Use of Consultants.
The  TA  is  estimated  to  cost  $575,000  equivalent,  of
which  $365,600  is  the  foreign  exchange  cost  and
$209,400  equivalent  the  local  currency  cost.  ADB  will
provide $365,600 to finance foreign exchange costs, and
$134,400 equivalent for local currency costs, on a grant
basis from the ADB-funded TA program. This will cover
consulting  services,  training,  and  equipment.  The
remaining  local  currency  costs  will  be  met  by  the
Government, through the provision of office space and
facilities, and counterpart staff.

I.  THE PROPOSAL
1. I submit for your approval the following Report and Recommendation on (i) a proposed
loan to the Independent State of Samoa for the Small Business Development Project; and (ii) a
proposed  equity  investment  in  a  Samoa  venture  capital  fund.  The  report  also  describes
proposed technical assistance (TA) for Capacity Building of Financial and Business Advisory
Intermediaries, and if the proposed loan and equity investment are approved by the Board, I,
acting under the authority delegated to me by the Board, shall approve the TA.
II.  INTRODUCTION
2. During the 1999 Country Programming Mission to Samoa, the Government requested
TA to develop a small business development project for the Asian Development Bank (ADB)
financing in 2000.1 ADB was to examine the feasibility of different components for such a
project, including (i) a dedicated credit line and/or guarantee scheme for micro- and small-
enterprises (MSEs); (ii) a pilot microfinance scheme; (iii) capacity building through the provision
of business advisory services; and (iv) an equity participation in a proposed venture capital fund
(VCF) being developed with the help of the South Pacific Project Facility (SPPF).2 The TA was
included in the 1999 country program, and the TA consulting team commenced work in Samoa
in March 2000. The ADB Appraisal Mission3 visited Samoa from 31 July to 9 August 2000. The
project framework for the proposed Small Business Development Project is in Appendix 1.
III.  BACKGROUND
A. Sector Description
1. Macroeconomic Context
a. Country Background
3. Samoa is an archipelago of seven islands located in the South Pacific, approximately
2,400  kilometers  (km)  northeast  of  New  Zealand.  The  total  population  of  the  country  is
estimated at 170,000. The average population density is 56 persons per square kilometer (km2),
although a large majority live in the coastal areas of the two main islands of Upolu (72 percent
of the population) and Savai'i (27 percent). About 35,000 (over 20 percent of the population) live
in Apia, the capital, on the island of Upolu. Because of the geographically compact nature of the
country and the existence of a good road and shipping network, transport between and within
islands is relatively easy, and access to Government services is generally good.
4. Samoa has a total land area of 2,820 km2, with an exclusive economic zone of 98,000
km2, the smallest in the Pacific. About 43 percent of the land area is classified as arable, and
approximately 75 percent of the population still use land and coastal resources as a main or
supplementary source of income. However, Samoa is ecologically fragile and vulnerable to

b. Public Sector/Financial Sector Reforms
5. The Government has been engaged in extensive public sector reforms since the mid-
1990s.  Recent  reforms  have  emphasized  improving  the  budget,  supporting  the  strategic
planning system, devolving some responsibilities to line agencies, introducing performance-
based budgeting, and restructuring state-owned enterprises (SOEs). Between 1987 and 1996,
21 SOEs were liquidated or privatized. More recent reforms included privatization of Samoa
Breweries Ltd, Samoa Iron and Steel Ltd, and BOC Gases Ltd. The Government corporatized
the Post and Telecommunications Department into Samoa Communications Ltd in July 1999.
6. With the ADB-financed Financial Sector Program (FSPL),4 since 1998 the Government
has been introducing far-reaching financial sector reforms. These reforms include (i) removing
all credit ceilings and interest rate controls as of 1 January 1998; (ii) phasing out the liquid
assets ratio as of September 1999, (iii) using of auctions as the primary monetary policy
instrument of the Central Bank of Samoa (CBS); (iv) allowing commercial banks to make
forward exchange contracts from mid-1998, and removing a 1 percent levy on foreign exchange
sales from January 1998; (v) partially removing foreign exchange controls on current account
transactions; (vi) allowing approved entities to operate as foreign exchange dealers effective
from mid-1999; (vii) closing the export financing facility, which provided funds for exporters at
subsidized rates; and (viii) strengthening the capacity of CBS, to manage liquidity and undertake
prudential supervision, and of the National Provident Fund (NPF) and the Development Bank of
Samoa (DBS).
c. Recent Economic Performance and Prospects
7. In 1999, the growth rate of the Samoan economy accelerated to 5.3 percent, from 3.4
percent in 1998. This reflected a 7.3 percent expansion in the tertiary sector, which accounted
for 56 percent of gross domestic product (GDP); a 4.4 percent expansion in the secondary
sector, which accounted for 23 percent of GDP; and a 2.4 percent expansion in the primary
sector,  which  accounted  for  21  percent  of  GDP.  Within  the  tertiary  sector,  strong  growth
occurred in hotels and restaurants (17.8 percent), largely as a result of a 9 percent increase in
tourist  arrivals  attributable  to  end  of  the  millennium  celebrations.  Transportation  and
communication, also stimulated in part by tourism growth, increased output by 13 percent; while
commerce increased output by 8.4 percent, continuing the steady growth that has made it the
largest sector of the economy since 1997. Public administration maintained its share of GDP,
growing by 5.1 percent, and personal and other services grew by 4.7 percent. Within the
secondary sector, notable growth of 13.4 percent was recorded in the construction sector, as
both  public  and  private  sector  projects  took  output  to  a  record  level.  Food  and  beverage
manufacturing declined slightly as a result of temporary closure of the coconut oil mill; but other
manufacturing increased output by 1.3 percent as the Yazaki automotive assembly operation
recovered from the effects of the Asian crisis, and a new garment factory began production.
Within the primary sector, fishing grew at 6.1 percent, compared with 31.8 percent in 1998,
while  agriculture  production  was  down  by  1.1  percent.  The  growth  acceleration  was
accompanied by a drop in the inflation rate to 0.3 percent, from 2.2 percent in 1998. Declining

8. The balance of payments remained in overall surplus of ST0.01 million in 1999, with a
capital account surplus just exceeding a current account deficit of ST58.3 million (8.1 percent of
GDP). The latter, more than double the 1998 deficit despite tourism growth and a 14 percent

were  stagnant  in  aggregate:  although  domestic  export  earnings  rose  10  percent,  reexport
earnings fell from the unusually high level of 1998. Net foreign assets reached ST183 million,
providing 6.3 months of import cover. The Government’s external debt declined to ST431.2
million at the end of 1999, or 60 percent of GDP; while debt servicing costs as a percentage of
merchandise exports reached 17.9 percent.
9. Government finance statistics show that, for the fourth fiscal year in succession, the
Government ran an overall budget surplus in 1998-99, equivalent to 0.3 percent of GDP,
although an overall deficit of 1.3 percent of GDP was budgeted. Revenue was slightly below the
original budget estimate because of a shortfall in tax revenue, but the current balance was close
to expectations because of below-budget current expenditure. Externally funded development
expenditure was also below the budgeted level because of delays in the start-up of some
projects. As a result of the surplus, the Government increased its net deposits in the banking
system, reinforcing the absence of crowding out pressure on the private sector. In fiscal year
1999/2000, an overall deficit of 3.1 percent of GDP was budgeted, to be financed by external
borrowing. Revenue and current expenditure were projected to rise by 8.2 percent and 6.6
percent leaving a current surplus of 3.4 percent of GDP. Budget outturns for the first half of the
fiscal year were broadly in line with budget estimates. However, it was questionable if above-
budget tax revenue collections would continue to offset a shortfall in nontax revenue, and if the
Government would be able to achieve the targeted improvement in its net credit position with
the banking system.
10. Broad money supply (M2) increased by 13 percent in 1999, compared with 5 percent in
1998. This expansion was entirely attributable to a rise in net domestic assets, with credit to the
private sector growing by 17.6 percent. Credit extended to public institutions increased by 4.2
percent;  while  Government  reduced  its  net  credit  position  by  5.8  percent,  partly  to  make
advance payments on overseas debt to avoid possible year 2000 computer problems. All
categories of commercial bank loans to the private sector showed significant growth, including
loans to agriculture, forestry, and fisheries. This last development demonstrated the impact of
financial sector liberalization. Historically, banks were reluctant to lend to the primary sector, not
only because of problems in obtaining acceptable security for loans, but also because direct
controls on interest rates prevented the charging of a sufficient risk premium in lending rates.
With the removal of direct controls in the financial sector, loans to agriculture, forestry, and
fisheries have grown from ST1.50 million in 1997 to ST4.5 million in 1999. The weighted
average lending rate of commercial banks fell slightly to 12.6 percent in 1999, from 12.8 in
1998, while the weighted average deposit rate remained at 5.1 percent. The interest rate spread
thus declined to 7.5 percent in 1999 and has remained at that level in 2000 as lending and
deposit rates both fell by 0.2 percent.
11. In the context of ongoing stability in the macroeconomic environment, and continued
improvement in the microeconomic policy environment, an economic growth rate of around 4
percent is expected in 2000. Allowing for the seasonal downturn in economic activity that
characterizes the first quarter of the year, tourism remained robust early in the year; and a

2. The Small Business Sector
12. Most of the private sector enterprises in Samoa are MSEs. The Business Activity Survey
for 1994, largely covering enterprises registered with NPF, showed that there are about 586
MSEs in Samoa. Formal private sector enterprises (excluding the Yazaki plant) employ a total of
7,643. About 80 percent of these enterprises employ less than 20 employees. A more recent
study commissioned by the Department of Trade, Commerce and Industry (DTCI), which also
included self-employed people with business licenses, identified a total of 1,528 businesses,
with over 80 percent having 5 employees or less.
13. Government policies do not differentiate between various sizes of businesses other than
through  the  value  added  goods  and  service  tax  (VAGST)  Act  1998,  which  principally
differentiates on the basis of turnover. The VAGST threshold is currently set at ST52,000. The
formal  private  sector  characteristics  can  be  determined  in  general  terms  through  various
sources  of  data  collection,  principally  business  licenses,  VAGST  registrations,  and  NPF
contributions. Over 50 percent of all businesses operating in the formal sector are owner or
family operated, with no employees, with a further 39 percent having 5 or less employees.
14. The formal sector is dominated by retail trade activities, with a total of 1,071 businesses
registered for VAGST as of 31 March 2000. This represents a 49.3 percent increase over the
717 businesses identified in the 1997 Bioglobal Pacific/DTCI study. The hotel and restaurant
trade, at 138 businesses, recorded a 40.8 percent increase in the two years following the
Bioglobal study. Substantial growth has occurred in fisheries, with in excess of 400 aluminum
boats now operating in the tuna industry. GDP grew by 7.0 percent, at current market prices
over the six years from 1994 to 1999, with most of that occurring since 1996. The low entry
investment cost for boats, high returns, and the resolution of issues relating to market access by
establishing a number of fish processing plants has led to this prolific growth. The private sector
claims the credit for fisheries development. However, because fishing activities are exempt as a
taxable income, Inland Revenue does not capture data.
15. Because agricultural producers do not need a license and are exempt from taxation, no
substantive data exists from which the size and nature of the informal MSE sector can be
estimated.  However,  some  data  sources  can  be  used  to  make  provisional  assumptions.
Nationally,  11.2  percent  of  all  annual  household  income  comes  from  the  sale  of  surplus
products or handicrafts; only 3.3 percent of income from the individual businesses. Although a
percentage of the population rely heavily on the sale of home-grown or produced items as their
major source of income, the implication here is that generally, Samoans do not regard such sale
as a business activity, but rather a surplus from subsistence-type lifestyles. Table 1 provides a
summary of household income sources.

5. Key Constraints
27. Lack  of  information  on  the  MSE  sector  and  policy  formulation.  The  political
environment is generally supportive of private sector development. While a special and separate
MSE  promotion  policy  does  not  exist,  there  are  policies  related  to  and  relevant  for  small
investment projects. In general, information on major parameters of businesses in Samoa and

9
their problems and needs is lacking, in particular on unregistered informal sector activities.
While data for the formal sector of registered businesses indicate that around 80 percent of
enterprises  have  up  to  5  employees,  no  data  is  available  for  unregistered  businesses  in
agriculture and fisheries, cottage industries and handicrafts, some microscale trading, and other
income-generating activities.
28. Land tenure. About 80 percent of the land is customary land. With freehold land as the
major type of collateral required by banks, the land tenure system is a constraint in terms of
enterprise  financing.  Related  to  this  is  the  value  of  long-term  land  leases  as  collateral
substitutes.  While  long-term  leasing  of  plots  is  possible  and  common  outside  of  Apia,
mortgaging these leasehold interests and using them as security for loans, is generally not
considered permissible or practical at present under existing law. Land tenure is also a factor to
be considered when new premises are needed for a business or for expansion of agricultural
production. While reform of the land tenure system is necessary and would be beneficial for
business and commercial agriculture development, other considerations, social and cultural,
need to be considered.
29. Chattel mortgages. Because of the unsatisfactory nature of the registries recording
securities granted over personal property (i.e., chattels), the commercial banks have been
moving away from the use of chattels as collateral, thereby reducing the options available to
MSEs to obtain lines of credit. Financial institutions identify the Chattels Transfer Act 1975 and
the Companies Act 1955 as having several unsatisfactory features in this regard; both are
currently being reviewed with a view to major amendment or repeal.
30. Social  and  cultural  factors.  Particularly  in  rural  areas,  MSEs  are  operating  in
environments characterized by traditional village and family authority and leadership, as well as
high financial demands for social and cultural events, strong mechanisms of redistribution within
extended family structures, and support to churches. Target incomes of rural households are
often met by a mixture of subsistence production, some wage income, and some remittances of
family members working abroad. Keeping money in the business can be difficult due to social
reciprocity and redistribution requirements. This environment does not necessarily encourage
business activity; but rather provides disincentives for entrepreneurship.
31. Markets  and  business  opportunities.  In  a  small  country  with  a  limited  domestic
market, lack of markets and opportunities is a major constraint for enterprise development. The
small enterprise sector can only grow if at the same time new and additional domestic as well as
export niche markets are identified and developed. For example, the existence of large Samoan
communities abroad is an opportunity that hasn't been fully exploited. The same is valid for the
tourist market in Samoa where the possibilities of raising the tourists’ interest in cultural and
handicraft products seems to be far from fully exploited. There are other potential and new
markets, e.g., in fishing, organic agriculture, agricultural processing, cut flower production, and
exports, which provide potential for increased participation of small entrepreneurs.
32. Entrepreneurship and business management capabilities. Some of the local social
and cultural factors tend to discourage rather than encourage entrepreneurship. At the same
time, macroeconomic reforms and liberalization have created a new, private sector-oriented
climate, and new opportunities. The young are growing up with aspirations other than working
on the land. However, rural society is still in the earliest stage of being affected and mobilized by
the new climate created by macroeconomic reforms. The potential for entrepreneurship and
business development is unexploited. Due to lack of business experience, potential and existing

10
MSE  entrepreneurs  lack  entrepreneurial,  marketing,  production,  and  financial  management
skills and competencies.
33. Debt financing. In principle, credit is available for investment funding through products
such  as  small  loans,  personal  loans,  or  term  loans  from  commercial  banks  and  nonbank
financial institutions in all size categories up to around ST500,000. The constraints lie in the
terms at which loans are given: repayment periods and collateral requirements.
34. Credit  reference  facility.  The  absence  of  a  credit  reference  facility  also  frustrates
commercial lending institutions' processing of requests for finance by these small enterprises,
particularly  where  third  party  personal  guarantees  form  an  essential  aspect  of  security
arrangements.
35. Equity financing. Representatives of the Samoa Chamber of Commerce and Industry
and the Samoa Manufacturers' and Exporters' Association, as well as bankers, have repeatedly
noted that small enterprises need access to longer-term maturity funding rather than short-term
loans, and in particular to equity rather than only credit. Equity needs of medium-size business
may have been catered to by some regional initiatives, but smaller enterprises have basically no
access to venture capital. This is the rationale behind the proposed Samoan VCF; Government,
private sector, and representatives have repeatedly advocated improved provision of venture
capital to Samoan enterprises.
36. Microfinance service providers. The introduction of the Grameen Bank approach with
loans exclusively to women, and through joint collateral and the group mechanism was not
successful in Samoa. Apart from the WIBF, no specialized microfinance institutions exist in
Samoa. Along with training and other services, WIBF provides some microfinancing but has
barely enough capacity to handle the current level of incoming external funding. However, there
are institutions that provide financial services that fall in the microfinance bracket. A lack of
capacity among the pilot organizations to account and monitor the lines of credit, coupled with
restrictions imposed on the lending institutions, has prohibited them from offsetting the high
risks associated with lending to the target group with higher interest rates, and thus limited their
participation in such schemes.
B. Government Policies and Plans
37. The Samoan economy is emerging from a process of transition, with a more market-
oriented environment now in place. The Government has embarked on a partnership with the
private sector, with public sector policies and programs increasingly focusing on creating an
enabling environment for the private sector. The Government is reinforcing this partnership by
providing  funding  to  the  Samoa  Chamber  of  Commerce  and  Industry  and  the  Samoa
Manufacturers' and Exporters' Association to purchase professional assistance to prepare policy
submissions for Government consideration.
38. The Government’s policies are elaborated in the biannual SES (para. 11). The most
recent SES, covering 2000-2001 reinforces the Government’s intention to achieve a more
equitable distribution of economic benefits nationally, in particular to the rural areas and the
village  economies.  Consolidation  of  Samoa’s  position  as  a  competitive,  enterprise-based
economy will be pursued to ensure sustained economic growth. This growth is to be based on a
strong and diversified private sector. The SES emphasizes that the creation of employment
opportunities through village and urban-based enterprises will be essential to sustain growth
and spread the benefits throughout the economy.

11
39. In terms of policies to facilitate private sector-led growth, the Government proposes the
following measures: (i) improve availability of land for investment and utilize customary land as
collateral; (ii) provide a sound financial and business environment conducive to a thriving private
sector; and (iii) support SBEC to provide assistance and training to small enterprises in urban
and rural areas.
40. Major reforms relevant to small business development have taken place in the areas of
tax  and  tariff  reduction  and  simplification,  liberalization  of  the  financial  sector,  removal  of
incentives, and corporatization or privatization of public sector assets. These reforms are having
a  positive  impact  on  the  economy.  As  part  of  freeing  up  the  economy,  the  Government
introduced a series of policy initiatives. Tariffs on imported goods have been streamlined and
simplified, with a smaller range of tariffs of up to 20 percent being imposed. The private sector
has responded positively to this move. The company tax was reduced to 29 percent, effective 1
January 2000, and as a trade-off for the removal of government incentives and tax relief
holidays, accelerated write-off of depreciation is possible for new assets. The threshold below
which no personal income tax is deducted was increased from ST8,000 to ST10,000.
41. The Government also liberalized the financial sector, under its Financial Sector Program.
Banks have generally responded favorably, and are now pricing credit according to the risk
profile of the applicant.
42. The VAGST threshold was increased from ST30,000 to ST52,000, in recognition of the
high compliance cost burden on microenterprises and difficulties in policing, but with higher
penalties being imposed on those continuing to evade taxes. Business licenses were simplified
by the Business License Act 1998. Inland Revenue now is the only institution involved in
processing and issuing licenses. License fees have increased from ST200 to ST300 per annum,
and generally no distinction is made on the size of the business. Fishing and agricultural
activities have been exempted from holding a business license or from paying VAGST.

D. Lessons Learned
49. Several important lessons learned arising from ADB-financed projects in Asia and the
Pacific are relevant to the proposed Project. First, legal and regulatory reforms should precede
or  at  least  accompany  direct  project  interventions.  Provision  of  lending  from  development
finance  institutions  has  been  less  than  successful.  Innovative  approaches  are  needed  to
improve the quality of financial services in the Pacific developing member countries (PDMCs).
Project interventions in the financial sector have to be accompanied by reforms pertaining to
land-related issues. While these reforms have proved to be a challenge, they can not be
avoided in the long term. An important lesson learned is that funding should be provided only to
institutions  that  are  fully  autonomous  in  their  decision  making  and  management;  have
identifiable  performance  indicators;  and  are  accountable  for  their  performance  in  terms  of
profitability, efficiency, and risks reported under commercial financial management covenants.
Institutional strengthening of participating financial institutions is very important.
50. Furthermore, financial services by themselves are not sufficient to facilitate growth in
rural  areas.  Business  advisory  and  training  services  are  important.  Although  agencies  do
provide training and business advice to microentrepreneurs, including government agencies,
business advisory centers, NGOs, and business development units of development banks,
these services are not coordinated.
51. In terms of Samoa, the most successful of the models dealing with access to credit has
been the SBEC Small Business Loans Guarantee Scheme (SBLGS). To date, there have been
no drawdowns against the guarantee facility despite it operating since 1994. The SBLGS has a
strong link between pre and post loan approval support, through a combination of training,
business  advice,  and  monitoring.  The  scheme's  strength  is  that  the  lending  institutions
recognize it as a guarantee of last resort, and therefore, any client must meet all normal bank
lending criteria, other than collateral. The banks' involvement in the approval and subsequent
monitoring of repayment is a specific strength. The SBEC approach of combining training with
business advice, mentoring, and a loan guarantee scheme is a model that is working well in the
Pacific, although measures of performance continue to be based more on activities (number of

13
training courses held, number of clients seen) rather than a more qualitative approach of
measuring the impact of the project. SBEC emphasizes training, but lacks human resources to
provide adequate and regular follow-up of its client base.
52. SPPF has a good track record with the lending institutions, providing them with a full
bankable document, covering all aspects of the business, including a full market and technical
assessment. SPPF involvement in a project lends weight to the banks' favorable consideration
of the loan request. SBEC feeds larger projects into SPPF and vice versa.
53. WIBF  has  a  unique  holistic  approach  at  the  microenterprise  level,  which  combines
technical  training,  basic  entrepreneurship  training,  and  microfinance.  WIBF  uses  a  project
approach (for example, honey production or coconut oil), and takes the position of market
intermediary, thereby resolving market access issues for low production capacity individuals.
The WIBF microcredit facility is an adaptation of the Grameen Bank model, and incorporates a
savings component.
54. The microcredit scheme to the poorest of the poor provided by the International Fund for
Agricultural Development (IFAD), in areas most affected by the devastating cyclones of 1990

imposed a high delivery cost structure on the financial institutions involved: DBS, Samoa Credit

IV.  THE PROPOSED PROJECT
A.  Rationale
62. Since 1996, the Government has embarked on a process of economic reform and
liberalization that recognizes the private sector as the engine of growth. The reform process has
resulted in an environment that is conducive to economic growth. The Government SES has
consistently  reinforced  the  partnership  between  the  private  sector  and  Government.  After
focusing on the major macroeconomic reforms, the Government is now developing strategies to
broaden the spread of benefits of economic growth. A key component is the development of
infrastructure for the village economy, which centers on MSEs.
63. Financial sector liberalization, together with the introduction of tax and tariff reforms, has
created an environment more supportive of enterprise growth. The Government’s increased
emphasis  on  more  equitable  distribution  of  economic  benefits  nationally  is  leading  to
improvements in rural infrastructure. However, barriers still exist that could frustrate economic
growth, particularly at the MSE level. The Project will seek to address these barriers through two
parallel, but integrated lines of activity aimed at improving access to credit for MSE start-up,
expansion, and diversification, supported by business development service providers, who will
benefit from increased capacity and expansion of their existing services. Eighty-two percent of
all businesses in Samoa have five or fewer employees.
64. The potential for MSE development is considerable, particularly in the rural environment.
A generation of youth is growing up whose aspirations are no longer satisfied by living in
villages and working on the land. Youth unemployment has emerged as a new phenomenon.
While this is certainly somewhat an artificial phenomenon as long as extended families have
enough land available, it reflects social and cultural change of Samoan society and changing
aspirations. Improved availability of financial and nonfinancial business development services
will result in the creation and expansion of MSEs and thereby contribute to the generation of
additional income and employment opportunities. The Project reflects ADB's poverty reduction
strategy and private sector development strategies. The Government is committed to forging a
working partnership with the private sector; this should be encouraged by ADB.
B. Objectives and Scope
1. Objectives
65. Consistent with the Government's strategic objectives and SES, the project goal will be
to generate income and employment for MSEs. The Project will have two parallel, but integrated
objectives for MSEs: (i) growth through improved availability of financial services, and (ii) MSE
growth through improved access to business development support services.
66. While facilitating and diversifying financial intermediation in Samoa, the Project will seek
to address systemic issues related to faster market development, in particular by fostering an
enabling environment for companies and a more fluid land market.

16
2. Scope
67. The following four broad components are proposed for the Project: (i) expanded small
loans guarantee scheme; (ii) pilot microfinance scheme; (iii) enhancement of business advisory
services; and (iv) improvements to the policy and legislative environment for small business
development. In addition, an equity investment by ADB is proposed for a Samoa VCF.
a. Expanded Small Business Loans Guarantee Scheme
68. The current credit guarantee scheme, SBLGS, administered by SBEC, which is now
almost fully committed, will be enhanced under the Project to accommodate increasing demand.
The SBLGS will be promoted and managed by SBEC, and be open to DBS and the three
commercial banks. The guarantee fund will be held by CBS; the funds will be owned by the
Government. Interest earned on the principal invested will be reinvested as further capitalization
of  the  guarantee,  and  should  be  sufficient  to  cover  any  defaults.  SBLGS  operation  and
indemnity from liability for SBEC will be covered in a memorandum of agreement entered into
between CBS and SBEC. Individual guarantees to entrepreneurs will be underwritten by the
funds held in trust by CBS. The director, SBEC will have the delegated authority and discretion
to offer guarantees up to ST20,000. The guarantee will provide partial guarantee cover on the
principal sum only, for approved, commercially viable ventures. Borrowers will be expected to
meet all other normal bank lending criteria. The SBLGS will be available to both clients of SBEC
and any other participating organizations. Banks will be encouraged to copromote the scheme
through their own client base, and to refer clients to the SBLGS for consideration. SBEC will be
funded through the SBDF to provide regular loan and client monitoring and support to clients.
69. The existing scheme, which is almost 100 percent subscribed (up to the level currently
agreed to by the board of trustees), has an upper limit of ST20,000 per guarantee (80 percent of
principal)  over  two  years.  Recent  demand  for  the  SBLGs,  directly  associated  with  the
penetration into the rural sector, exceeds supply. Discussions with financial institutions has
identified that although the scheme is generally well accepted, there is some concern that term
loans in excess of two years are not covered for the life of the loan. Up to now, no guarantees
have been called in. The SBLGS will be modified so that guarantees issued will coincide with
the loan tenure, up to a maximum of five years.
70. A  gap  exists  in  the  market  for  loans  ranging  from  ST20,000-ST50,000,  where
businesses moving into second phase expansion have insufficient security to offer banks, and
are therefore being restricted in their capacity to expand the business, thus limiting the creation
of employment opportunities. The Project attempts to resolve this by making a second-tier
guarantee available within the ST20,000-ST50,000 range, specifically targeting only existing
businesses in an expansion and diversification mode, with the loan being covered by guarantee
for up to five years. Targeting the existing businesses will reduce the risk factor associated with
the higher guarantee level, as borrowers will need to demonstrate a proven track record in
managing an existing business over a minimum time period in order to qualify. In both cases,
the proposal will need to meet all other normal bank lending criteria, including adequate debt to
equity ratio, working capital, and demonstrated viability. Support for feasibility studies for the
larger projects could be provided by SPPF, given the limited capacity of SBEC to undertake a
full feasibility study to the bankable document stage. The director, SBEC will have the delegated
authority and discretion to offer guarantees up to ST20,000. Individual credit guarantees in
excess of ST20,000 will be submitted to a credit committee to be established within the project
management unit (PMU) for approval.

17
71. The fund will be invested in secure investments within the domestic financial markets,
with the interest earned being sufficient to cover any call on the guarantees. The guarantee will
be conditional on the payment of an application fee payable by the applicant on the sum
guaranteed. Income  earned  from  the  application  fee  will  be  reinvested  into  the  guarantee
scheme.
72. PFIs will utilize their own funds for lending covered under the SBLGS. Final approval
responsibility for applications under this scheme will remain with the PFIs, with clients expecting
to meet all normal bank lending criteria other than on the issue of collateral. The director, SBEC,
will be delegated the responsibility for offering credit guarantee support on amounts up to
ST20,000. A credit committee, comprising the manager of the PMU, a representative of the
Treasury Department, and the director of SBEC, will approve requests for guarantees in excess
of this amount. Access to the SBLGS will be limited to applicants who have an established
ongoing  relationship  with  SBEC,  and  are  agreeable  to  committing  to  regular  monitoring
throughout the guarantee period. SBEC will be funded through the SBDF to provide regular
follow-up and monitoring of entrepreneurs covered under the SBLGS.
73. Services to be provided through the SBLGS include guarantees of up to 80 percent of
principal with a minimum of ST5,000 and a maximum of ST20,000 with a term commensurate to
the term of the loan, at rates determined by the PFIs, with an application fee as determined by
the director of SBEC during periodic reviews in consultation with the project steering committee
(PSC). The PSC delegates authority for approving guarantees up to ST20,000 to the Director.
The target group for this service will be both existing and first time MSEs. The SBLGS will also
provide  guarantees  of  up  to  80  percent  of  the  principal  within  the  range  of  ST20,000  to
ST50,000 with a maximum repayment term of five years at rates determined by the PFIs, with
an application fee as determined by the SBEC director during periodic reviews in consultation
with the PSC. A credit committee will approve guarantees over ST20,000. The target group for
this service will be enterprises wanting to expand and diversify with a proven track record of
prudent management of their enterprise. In each case, the guarantee will be considered a
guarantee of last resort. The following eligibility criteria will apply for the SBLGS:
(i)  Geographic Area. Guarantees can be granted for projects anywhere in Samoa.
(ii)  Purpose. Guarantees can be issued only for legitimate and commercially viable
business  purposes  with  no  detrimental  environmental  or  social  impact.
Commercial viability will be determined by SBEC and be revalidated by the PFI
extending the loan. A commercially viable project should be able to demonstrate
the minimum following parameters:
(a)  sensitivity analysis of the major project variables (normally income and
costs) will demonstrate that the project has the capacity to maintain a
minimum of 1.0 x debt service cover after a 10 percent change in the
major variables;
(b)  minimum owners equity of 20 percent;
(c)  minimum 10 percent net profit after tax by year two;
(d)  adequate  market  research  to  confirm  the  availability  and  size  of  the
market for the product/service proposed;

(e)  adequate management skills of the project sponsor; and
(f)  financial  projections  are  used  to  formulate  realistic  underlying
assumptions.
(iii)  Borrowers. Guarantees can only be issued to permanent residents of Samoa.
Applicants will be screened to ensure that they would not otherwise qualify for a
bank loan.
(iv)  Sectors. Guarantees can be extended to any sector, subject to periodic reviews
as directed by the PSC from time to time, based on priority sectors determined
by the Government in the SES.
b. Microfinance
74. CBS will set up a revolving fund facility and contract its management to DBS. The
facility’s borrowing cost is estimated at 6.5 percent in tala. During the first two years of the
experimental period, DBS will borrow from the facility and finance the approved projects, which
had been prepared by WIBF and/or other participating organizations. The lending rate charged
to  beneficiaries  is  expected  to  range  from  18-20  percent  per  annum.  WIBF  and  other
participating organizations will get a flat commission fee of 5 percent of the principal for their
assistance (project identification, advice, screening, appraisal, and monitoring services), while
DBS will assume the credit risks of the microfinance portfolio. At the end of the experimental
period, based on the Project’s review mission conclusion as well as the result of the pilot
program, the option to transfer the microfinance portfolio from DBS to WIBF and/or other
participating organizations will be decided.
75. DBS  will  assess  the  participating  organizations,  and  DBS  and  the  participating
organizations will agree on a training and capacity building program. Upon the completion of
these training activities, the participating organizations will have the capacity, systems, and
skills necessary to directly identify and manage a microfinance portfolio. The proposed training
program will be submitted to a subcommittee of the PSC for consideration for funding and
utilizing the SBDF. Opportunities to include other community-based institutions will be explored
during  the  process  of  the  first  two  years  of  the  experimental  period.  The  participating
organizations should meet the following minimum criteria:
(i)  Savings.  The  participating  organizations'  savings  mobilization  scheme  is
currently operating and its client base is growing at least 10 percent per year,
with the client’s average saving account balance not less than ST50.
(ii)  Management.  The  participating  organization  must  have  a  sound  history  of
managing microfinance loans and savings products, and be subject to annual
external audits. At least one management officer should have trained or been
retrained in a DBS training program under the business advisory service of this
Project.  Key  project  and  business  advisers  must  have  been  trained  and
accredited in the DBS program.
(iii)  Geographic  Area.  The  participating  organization  must  have  the  potential  to
cover  rural  and  urban  areas  nationwide  and  this  should  be  reflected  in  its
business/strategic plan.

19
(iv)  Purpose.  The  participating  organization  must  have  an  express  purpose  of
helping develop MSEs, and be capable of providing follow-up, monitoring, and
support activities. Loans must therefore specifically focus on the enterprises’
productive development, rather than consumption.
(v)  Accreditation. The participating organization must satisfy DBS with regard to
systems, management capacity, application of detailed operational procedures
for loan application processing, monitoring, and supervision.
(vi)  Loan. The microfinance facility must approve loans up to ST5,000, with a typical
loan being in the ST1,000-ST2,000 range for an average period up to 3 years.
(vii) Performance. The participating organization should target to have operational
sustainability during the first three years of its operations and reach financial

c. Enhancement of the Business Advisory Services
76. The Project will establish an SBDF, with the fund held by the Government, and invested
in investment instruments. Management of the SBDF will be through a subcommittee of the
PSC, comprising Treasury, DTCI, and DBS. The capital of the fund will be replenished on an
annual  basis  throughout  the  five-year  life  of  the  project.  The  SBDF  will  purchase  support
services and training from participating organizations.
77. The purpose of the SBDF is to provide a secure source of funding to expand the
capacity of NGO business development service (BDS) providers to deliver business training,
advice, and monitoring in response to the needs of the MSE sector.
78. Existing  BDS  providers  have  expanded  their  services  into  the  rural  area,  although
penetration and outreach is limited, largely as a result of a lack of resources to meet the needs
and demands of MSE entrepreneurs. Both WIBF and SBEC have offices operating in Upolu and
Savai'i, and both undertake regular field trips to monitor clients, provide training (both technical
and  training),  and  in  the  case  of  WIBF,  manage  a  microfinance  facility.  With  combined
experience in excess of 15 years working in the MSE sector, both organizations recognize the
need to combine access to credit with other nonfinancial support services, if MSE enterprises
are to succeed. However, delivery of services to the rural sector is time consuming and costly,
and funding is insufficient to meet all the demands.
79. The SBDF will purchase services from SBEC, WIBF, and other accredited POs on a fee
for service basis, based on agreed medium-term work plans, with measurable performance
indicators.  Performance  indicators  will  emphasize  outputs  and  outcomes,  rather  than  just
activities. Services for funding consideration will include loan monitoring and follow-up of clients
utilizing  either  the  guarantee  scheme  or  microfinance  facility.  The  BDS  providers  will  be
expected to recover a portion of the total cost of servicing the expanded client base through
fees charged to the client.
80. Annual contracts to training organizations for the provision of training, business advice,
and mentoring, appropriately justified in relation to needs and demand, provided to a recognized
standard, will be funded through the SBDF. Only submissions from accredited or certified
providers will be accepted for consideration. Accreditation or certification will be handled by
SBEC. Contracts will be approved on a competitive bid basis.

81. The following indicative benchmarks could be used to determine accreditation. (i) proven
track record of professional competency in the delivery of entrepreneurial training or support, (ii)
professional or academic qualifications of staff, and (iii) ability or willingness to bear 10 percent
of the delivery cost either through their own resources or by a levy on the client base.
82. The SBDF will link the activities of the microfinance facility and the loans guarantee
scheme. Both organizations will use the fund to identify opportunities and develop programs

d. Policy and Infrastructure Development
83. Evaluation, review, and adoption of policy needs for the small business sector will be the
main output of this component. The component will concentrate on the creation of a better
enabling environment for small business with an emphasis on reforms to corporate law, land law
(particularly as it relates to customary land), and chattels. A new credit reference scheme will be
covered under this component.
(i)  Company law. The Project will support the Government’s ongoing overhaul of
company law being conducted within the Justice Department;
(ii)  Land law. The Project will seek to build on the recommendations made in a 1999
UNDP  commissioned  report  including  revisions  to  existing  registration
procedures  for  customary  land  leases,  with  a  view  to  simplifying  these
procedures to facilitate the more economic use of customary land.10 A system of
valuation will be developed and the use of customary land leases as security will
be promoted among financial institutions;
(iii)  Chattels registry. The registration of security interests for personal property is
generally recognized as being in need of reform. The amendment or repeal of the
Companies Act 1955 will hasten that reform. Under the Project, the Chattels
Transfer Act 1975 will be reviewed and recommendations made for legislative
and administrative amendments. A new computerized system for registration of
vehicles charged as security for loans will be introduced, perhaps in conjunction
with the ongoing modernization of the police recording system for vehicles.
(iv)  Credit reference facility. The Project will promote establishing a database for a
credit reference facility; and the systems and rules for operating such a facility,
an operational manual is to be produced for the database. A self financing model
for the proposed credit facility will be developed, and the facility will be set up
within the private sector through the three commercial banks, the DBS, and NPF.

C. Proposed Equity Investment
84. The proposal for a VCF in Samoa arose as a result of the review of SPPF by the
International Finance Corporation (IFC)/Admiralty Study on Pacific Islands Financing Needs
1998. The study identified some generally available venture capital facilities in the region from
sources including IFC's Pacific Island Investment Facility, and the Papua New Guinea and Fiji
Islands-based Kula Fund. However, the former has a minimum investment limit of $100,000
(approximately ST300,000), and the latter also supports larger projects and had until recently
confined itself to Melanesia. Preparatory work to define the modalities of such a fund has been
done by SPPF and IFC itself (more details are provided in the Appendix 4).
1. Facility and Its Management
85. The recommended structure is a 100 percent equity-financed facility, investing by way of
a range of equity and quasi-equity instruments with the preferred instrument being venture
capital loans. The internal rate of return for this structure is 8.6 percent, which is below what is
expected  in  more  mature  markets,  but  this  is  partly  attributable  to  (i)  very  conservative
assumptions about the earnings of the typical investee company, (ii) delayed returns while the
investee overcomes initial losses, and (iii) high provisions for losses on equity investments.
Logically, a true VCF is preferably financed from equity. For Samoa, the proposed VCF is
forecast to be substantially funding expansion projects, at a somewhat lower risk than true
venture capital, and therefore some level of gearing is acceptable and lower loan losses are
more realistic.
86. With VCF investments likely to be primarily in established businesses, projected loan
losses should be significantly less than might be the case with mainly seed capital or true
venture investments. However, for the purpose of the model, a very conservative 25 percent
loan loss provision has been allowed for the outstanding portfolio. This produces revenue losses
from year 1, which may be too conservative an assumption when calculating internal rate of
return, but is a prudent safety factor.
87. The proposal is for the VCF to invest $240,000 (ST898,000) annually for seven years,
using total funding of $1,600,000 (ST5,987,000) from shareholders plus retained earnings. The
primary  shareholders  have  been  assumed  as  IFC,  ADB,  DBS,  NPF,  and  ANZ,  with  the
contributions from the DBS and NPF at 12.5 percent each, ADB at 25 percent, IFC at 40
percent and ANZ 10 percent.
88. A  two-tier  structure  of  two  legal  entities  is  proposed:  the  fund  (VCF)  and  a  fund
management company (FMC). An FMC is being formed in Samoa and structured in line with
other  management  companies  operating  small  funds  elsewhere  in  the  world,  under  IFC
supervision. In addition to this and in line with IFC policy on skills and technology transfer and
capacity  building  in-country,  this  FMC  is  being  established  with  the  view  to  becoming  a
standing-alone facility in the long term and as a vehicle to attract local Samoan investors to
supplant  the  original  shareholders  over  time.  The  FMC  will  be  a  special  purpose  vehicle
nominally capitalized by the investors and subsidized by assistance agencies. It will have a
management contract to oversee the VCF. The VCF board members will be appointed pro rata
to shareholding, with ordinary shares carrying preemptive rights to enable primary sponsors to
maintain control of shareholding in the early years. FMC support staff will include three business
analysts and an administrative secretary. Two of the analysts are to be seconded for one to two
years from the DBS and the Samoa National Provident Fund to learn best practice equity and
quasi-equity investment and transfer those skills back to their organizations.

22
89. The original base case assumes that the aid agencies will meet the cost of the chief
executive officer's remuneration package, and other cash operating costs, for the first three
years, and the remuneration package thereafter. A model was prepared, which shows that the
portfolio size will need to roughly double, to $3.3 million (ST12,349,000), to produce comparable
returns if all costs are borne by the VCF. As the structure is under review, these costs and how
they  are  to  be  met,  are  not  yet  finalized.  However,  the  Australian  and  New  Zealand
governments have made an agreement in principle on meeting the original base-case operating
costs and salaries on a 50:50 basis for the first three years with a review for any additional
subsidies.
2. Target Market and Investment Instruments
90. VCF investments are likely to be primarily in established businesses. The target market
for the VCF is venture capital investments of less than $100,000 (ST374,200). Recommended
limits are ST50,000-ST250,000 with an upper limit of 50 percent of the total equity (including the
VCF contribution) for existing businesses and 40 percent for new ventures. Project size is
therefore expected to range from roughly ST200,000-ST1,200,000 with between 70-80 percent
likely to be expansion or diversification projects. The investment focus will be on projects that
contribute to economic growth and, in particular, earn or save foreign exchange.
91. The preferred investment instrument will be straight debt instruments—venture capital
loans—because of the relatively small size of the investments, the cost of putting investments in
place, and to simplify exit options. While this is the simplest instrument, the VCF will be able to
use all other normally accepted equity and quasi-equity instruments subject to well-documented
criteria. The financial model is based on the venture loan option, which is likely to be used in the
majority of cases. The original base case recommended interest to be 20 percent per annum on
venture capital loans to reflect the risk involved in unsecured investments. Commercial interest
rates have been decreasing in Samoa, and the base will be adjusted to better reflect the market.
Other income will be earned from application and establishment fees, each 1 percent of the
amount invested.
3. Development Value
92. There is a clear gap in the market for equity and quasi-equity funding for the large group
of undercapitalized businesses. No formal mechanism exists for businesses to obtain venture
capital funding of less than $100,000 (ST374,200). This is placing a severe constraint on the
ability of the Samoan business community to generate growth in the economy. Therefore the
VCF has the capacity to make a substantial impact on desired growth sectors generally, and
with particular emphasis on fishing, tourism, food processing, and manufacturing.
93. Total investment by the VCF over 7-8 years of $1.7 million-2.7 million (ST63.5 million-
ST10 million), at the normal contributions of sponsor equity, could have a multiplier effect by
creating up to $10 million (ST37,420,000) of new investment over the period. That level of total
investment would be expected to create a substantial number (estimated minimum 500, likely
considerably more) additional jobs, vital to an economy where job creation is lagging well
behind other growth projections and is a major policy aim for the Samoan Government.

V. PROJECT JUSTIFICATION
A.  Financial and Economic Analyses
1. The SBLGS and Microfinance Components
114. Financial and economic analyses were carried out for a typical range of projects to be
covered under the SBGLS, or financed through the microfinance facility, based on an evaluation
of the client portfolio of WIBF and SBEC, and field visits by the project preparatory TA team.
The sample should be regarded as indicative only as other sub-borrowers activities will be
included for financing under the Project. The analyses were undertaken to ensure that those
subprojects considered most likely to be financed under the Project could generate sufficient
income for subborrowers to repay their loans and generate surplus income.
115. The selected subprojects are diversified to reflect the Project's intended geographic
coverage. Six subprojects have been chosen out of numerous rural finance proposals. Three of
the six focus on agricultural production, another two are applicable for both rural and urban
areas, and the sixth focuses on commercial business in rural areas. The financing scope of
these subprojects ranges from the lowest initial investment of ST2,403 for a cocoa plantation to
the highest of ST38,500 for beach resort building activities. To compare the subproject, their
financial plans were transformed into 10-year undertakings. In general, the summary of financial

28
analysis confirms potential demand for sustainable funding in rural areas. Financial internal
rates of return were estimated for selective subprojects with multiyear investments and returns.
The subprojects are delivering a range of acceptable returns from 17 percent to 169 percent. (A
summary  of  the  financial  and  sensitivity  analysis  of  selected  subprojects  is  available  in  a
supplementary appendix).
116. Economic analysis was carried out for the same subprojects as identified for the financial
analysis,  and  for  the  same  time  span  assumptions.  For  nontradable  prices,  the  standard
conversion factor of 0.8 was applied. The economic cost of labor was estimated using an
appropriate  defined  shadow  rate  for  expensive  family  labor  of  0.85,  which  includes  both
management and normal labor cost. Economic internal rates of return (EIRRs) were calculated,
showing a range from 18 percent (cattle fattening) to 147 percent (taro planting). The EIRRs
demonstrate  the  subprojects'  economic  viability.  The  main  EIRR  increases  for  the  retail
subproject can be justified on the basis of the large import input costs associated with this
project.
117. A sensitivity analysis was also carried out to test the financial viability of subprojects.
Project sensitivity was tested on two variables (i) a 10 percent decrease in revenues, (ii) a
similar rate increase in overall costs, and (iii) the potential benefits delayed by one year. The
three tested scenarios show that retail, taxi, and cattle fattening subprojects become very
sensitive to the first two assumptions, but all subprojects subsequently have adverse impacts of
benefits and revenues being delayed by one year. The taxi subproject could easily be financially
unsustainable, and cattle fattening turns out to be economically unacceptable in the third tested
scenario. All subprojects are more susceptible to changes in revenue than cost increases, which
are characteristic of rural finance activities.
2. Venture Capital Fund
118. The market study estimated some 250 businesses (60 percent of which were identified
existing businesses) could take advantage of venture capital investment funds. In a market of
less than 1,000 commercial-sized businesses, this is a substantial percentage. If businesses are
not able to undertake the expansion of which they are capable, then the economy as a whole
experiences serious commercial loss. A relatively small outlay on the part of the VCF sponsors
could make a significant contribution to closing this investment gap.
119. Total investment by the VCF over 7-8 years of $1.2 million-$2.7 million (ST5 million-ST8
million), at the normal contribution of sponsor equity and debt, could have a multiplier effect of
creating up to $10 million (ST30 million) of new investment over the period. That level of total
investment would be expected to create a substantial number of additional jobs (an estimated
minimum of 500, likely well in excess of this) vital to an economy where job creation is lagging
well behind other growth projections and is a major policy aim for the Samoan Government.
120. The proposed equity investment in the VCF is a logical extension of the policy dialogue
conducted under the Financial Sector Program, aimed at liberalizing the financial sector and
increasing the range of financial instruments and players. ADB investment will play a catalytic
role and attract participation from other multilateral and local financial institutions. It will be also
demonstrational, and if successful, will create a model for other PDMCs to follow. Setting up of
the VCF coupled with the recent liberalization of the financial sector under the Financial Sector
Program will facilitate development of capital markets in Samoa.

29
3. Nonquantifiable Benefits
121. A  substantial  number  of  nonquantifiable  benefits  will  accrue  from  the  Project.  The
institutional strengthening of SBEC and WIBF, along with the establishment of more sustainable
funding  arrangements  for  BDS  providers,  will  ensure  improved  access  to  these  services.
Improving the management skills and instilling a business-like discipline among entrepreneurs
will enhance overall success of the business sector. With the anticipated financial and economic
benefits generated within the target group, the standard of living will increase.
B. Social Dimensions
122. The Project will have a positive social impact on employment and the rural village
economies. The most important target group in functional terms to benefit from the Project will
be  MSE  entrepreneurs  who  require  additional  finance  to  start,  expand,  or  diversify  their
enterprises. The results of field surveys are included in a supplementary appendix.
123. Within the specified target groups, rural households, and in particular the women of
these households, residing away from the urban areas, with no direct source of household
income  derived  from  regular  wages,  will  be  primary  beneficiaries  from  the  financial  and
supplemental technical and business training and advice provided through the Project. Project
collaboration with WIBF will directly impact on the economic status of these women and young
people as part of the more vulnerable subtarget group.
124. The Project will also have specific positive benefits for the people of Savai'i by retaining
a portion of the SBLGS specifically for enterprises located on Savai'i. The BDS providers
selected  for  participation  in  the  Project  have  strong  distribution  mechanisms  to  and
representation on Savai'i.
125. The  Government  is  committed  to  achieving  a  more  equitable  spread  of  economic
benefits from the liberalization and structural reforms that have already been enacted. These
reforms  have  created  a  more  enabling  environment  for  entrepreneurial  development.  The
Project will contribute to the Government objective by improving access of MSE entrepreneurs,
particularly in the rural sector, to financial, business training, and business advisory services,
thus allowing more rural households to develop income-generating activities.
126. Overall, the Project is expected to contribute to poverty reduction by improving access of
MSE entrepreneurs to credit, and business development services, thus facilitating income-
generating activities. During the five years of project implementation, without taking into account
peripheral effects, the Project is expected to directly create an additional 1,400 income and
employment opportunities, benefiting 5,600 people.
C. Impact on Poverty
127. In general, absolute poverty has not been regarded as a problem in Samoa. GDP per
capita is in excess of $1,200. Private remittance flows from Samoans living abroad have been
substantial;  and  the  extended  family  system  has  functioned  as  an  effective  means  of
redistributing income. Samoa’s human poverty index is the fourth lowest among the PDMCs
after  Tonga,  the  Cook  Islands,  and  the  Fiji  Islands.11  The  index  score  of  5.9  reflects  the
relatively low percentage of people not expected to survive to the age of 40 (10.3 percent); the
                                                          
11UNDP. 1999. Pacific Human Development Report 1999: Creating Opportunities.

30
low illiteracy rate (4.3 percent); the low percentage of people without access to safe water (10
percent); the fact that all have access to health services; and the relatively high percentage of
children under 5 years of age who are underweight (17 percent). A poverty analysis was
undertaken as part of the UNDP Poverty Strategies Initiative Project in Samoa.12 Studies were
conducted to assess food poverty, basic needs poverty, and relative poverty. Using a model diet
formulated by the Department of Health’s Nutrition Center, the food poverty analysis concluded
that 48 percent of households did not have sufficient income to meet their estimated food
requirements.  Of  these,  the  majority  were  in  the  rural  areas  of  Savai'i,  and  Upolu,  with
households in the urban Apia area faring slightly better. The relative poverty analysis also
highlighted the rural areas of Samoa as being most vulnerable to poverty, with Savai'i as the
region of most concern. However, the survey data were of questionable value because of
sampling problems, and the food poverty line was set unusually high. The Government intends
to conduct another survey in 2001 to provide reliable data for poverty measurement.
128. Poverty is not mentioned in the SES, and no actions are provided to reduce poverty.
Poverty is not seen, in the absolute sense, as a critical issue in the Samoan context. At the
same time, the concept of relative poverty has applicability. The Government is seeking to
facilitate broader based, and thus more inclusive, economic growth by implementing its current
economic strategy. High priority is given to improving access to education and health services,
and to revitalizing the agriculture sector. The Government’s rural development program aims to
improve infrastructure (power, transport, and communications) throughout the country, thereby
creating opportunities for those living in rural areas.
129. Sustainable  improvements  in  livelihoods  will  always  be  threatened  by  Samoa’s
vulnerability to external economic shocks and natural disasters, over which there is virtually no
control.  Poverty  and  vulnerability  are  linked  as  the  latter  threatens  the  sustainability  of
livelihoods.  The  United  Nation’s  Conference  on  Trade  and  Development  has  calculated  a
composite  vulnerability  index  that  placed  Samoa  in  20th  place  among  111  developing
countries.13 The Commonwealth vulnerability index ranks Samoa in the group of countries
characterized by high vulnerability.14 Market-based economic diversification may reduce the
extent  of  aggregate  export  instability,  and  good  economic  management  can  prevent  the
translation of such instability into general macroeconomic instability.
D. Risks
130. Risk areas for the project include continuing adherence of the Government to public
sector reforms and private sector development in the aftermath of the parliamentary elections
scheduled  for  the  first  half  of  2001.  Given  the  broad  consensus  in  Samoa  regarding  the
economic policy, current market-oriented policies are likely to be sustained irrespective of what
Government is in place. At the same time, land-related issues remain sensitive in Samoa, as
well as in many other PDMCs. While the Project calls for reforms related to the economic use of
customary  land,  these  issues  are  unlikely  to  be  fully  resolved  within  five  years  of  project
implementation.
