131. While current macroeconomic conditions are quite stable, underpinned by the robust
private sector growth, and continuing strong remittances from abroad, these conditions could
deteriorate,  either  because  of  the  slower  growth  in  exports,  due  to  the  change  in  market
situation, or decline in remittances. These risks are considered acceptable given the latest
positive developments in the economy. Furthermore, Samoa will always be vulnerable to natural
disturbances similar to devastation cause by the two major cyclones in 1990 and 1991, and the
adverse impact of taro leaf blight disease in 1992-1994.
132. Risks could arise from the weak demand for the SBEC credit guarantee scheme, slow
take up of investments by the VCF, and unforeseen weakening of institutional capacities of the
IAs.  These  risks  are  considered  acceptable  due  to  the  recent  record  of  the  SBEC  credit
guarantee scheme, and demand assessments conducted during the feasibility study for the
VCF. Continuing strong growth of Samoa’s economy will underpin the demand. Furthermore,
the Project will include mitigating measures directed at institutional strengthening of the IAs.
133. The key country risk for external investors appears to be acceptable in view of the stable
political environment and the fiscally responsible stance of the Samoan Government. The prime
market risk is the small market size, and the relatively undeveloped secondary industry sector.
Further risk arises from the importance of expatriate remittances and aid agencies’ contributions
to the Samoan gross national product (10-20 percent each). However, both contributions have
been stable over time. Clear independence from Government intervention is also a desirable
state,  especially  if  Government  institutions  are  represented  among  the  shareholders  and
directors.  Investee  risk  in  small-scale  businesses  is  largely  within  the  management  of  the
business, i.e., the management is the risk. The main mitigating factors will be the objectivity,
competence, and analytical skills of VCF management and staff, and tight investment criteria to
eliminate the higher risk applicants. Liquidity should be adequate if the shareholders set up and
fund the VCF as proposed.
134. There is a risk that while preparatory work is being done, and IFC has confirmed its
continued interest in the VCF, the VCF may not materialize. The structure and shareholding
could change in the process of preparatory work. The current indication is that IFC, which does
not need board approval for the investment of the proposed magnitude, will make a decision
before the end of 2000. Risks will be mitigated by the fact that any actual ADB investment in the
VCF  is  contingent  on  IFC  participation,  as  the  lead  investor.  ADB  will  continue  close
consultations with SPPF and IFC on VCF structure and shareholding.
135. The participating organizations, particularly at the grassroots level, have very limited
capacity to support additional demands that could arise as a result of this Project. Unless the
institutional strengthening components result in improved capacity and sustainability of the
participating organizations, the implementation of all programs proposed for the Project could
actually weaken them. Grassroot organizations are particularly susceptible to staff turnover
because of low staff numbers. SBEC, Samoa Credit Union League, and WIBF are particularly
vulnerable in this area, and a high staff attrition rate could affect their continued capacity to
contribute to the Project. This risk area is being addressed through capacity building TA.

OVERVIEW OF THE FINANCIAL SECTOR
A. Background
1. The financial system of Samoa comprises the Central Bank of Samoa (CBS), three
private commercial banks (two foreign-owned and one locally owned), and six nonbank financial
institutions  (NBFIs).  Under  the  Financial  Institutions  Act  of  1996,  CBS  performs  a  normal
prudential regulation role (including on-site inspection of the three locally commercial banks,
which are all locally incorporated; is responsible for conducting monetary and exchange rate
policy;  and  manages  part  of  the  country’s  foreign  exchange  reserves.  Under  the  Asian
Development Bank's (ADB) Financial Sector Program loan (FSPL), CBS is being strengthened.
Improvements are taking place in management information and accounting systems and CBS’s
budgetary reporting is being strengthened to support key responsibilities and provide greater
transparency. Public sector management reforms, including a corporate plan and performance
and output-based budgeting are key initiatives for CBS over the next two years.
B. Legal and Regulatory Environment
2. Monitoring and supervision takes place in the Financial Institutions Department of CBS;
supervision is currently confined to the commercial banks. The prudential guidelines issued in
March 1996 by CBS are consistent with the Financial Institutions Act 1996 and with standards
adopted worldwide. Compliance with these guidelines is being monitored by CBS. CBS is also
strengthening monitoring of bank compliance with these guidelines with assistance from ADB
technical assistance (TA). Compliance with core principles agreed by the Basle Committee of
Supervisors  (BIS)  is  also  satisfactory.  The  capital  adequacy  ratio  (CAR)  as  a  minimum
percentage of risk-weighted assets and other exposures has been set at no less than 15
percent. Tier 1 capital can be no less than 7.5 percent while tier II capital cannot exceed 100
percent of tier 1 capital.
3. Commercial banks are subject to a system of detailed regular reporting with reports
analyzed  in  relation  to  prudential  standards  as  detailed  above.  The  two  foreign-owned
commercial banks exceed the minimum while the locally owned National Bank of Samoa (NBS)
has  a  capital  ratio  of  about  the  minimum.  The  net  open  position  of  banks  is  now  fully
implemented with prudential procedures and data monitored on a weekly basis. The prudential
statement on provisioning increasing general provisions from 1 to 2 percent is proceeding.
Banks are also permitted to lend an equivalent of no more than 25 percent of capital to any one
borrower.
4. The NBFIs are not subject to prudential guidelines at present. The FSPL calls for CBS to
extend its prudential supervision to nonbank financial institutions to better protect the stability of
the financial system (requiring amending the legislation). These institutions engaged in banking
activities should be subject to the same supervisory and prudential framework as banks, so as
to ensure a level playing field. Although agreement in principle has been reached to having the
Development Bank of Samoa (DBS) and the National Provident Fund (NPF) report to CBS
under its prudential supervision requirements, the necessary statutory changes are still awaited
for the Financial Institutions Act.
5. CBS is being reorganized so that departmental responsibilities are more focused to a
liberalized  financial  system.  As  part  of  this,  procedures  in  CBS  are  being  strengthened,
including  supervision  procedures  and  strengthening  prudential  matters  including  liquidity
requirements are being considered by the Financial Institutions Department. The capacity of

each holding 43 percent equity stake and private domestic interests holding the remaining 14

D. Nonbank Financial Institutions
1.  National Provident Fund
16. NPF was established under the NPF Act of 1972. The act does not include specific
guidelinesm, but places NPF board in the position of trustee. The board has interpreted this to
mean that they should be ultra cautious in their investments. Their major investment areas are
(i) property loans (residential and commercial); (ii) members loans (e.g., housing, school fees);
and (iii) freehold property loans. However in December 1998, several amendments to the NPF
Act were passed by Parliament, including: (i) that members’ interests are to be paramount in the
administration of the fund; (ii) the fund can now invest up to 10 percent of its investment funds
overseas, and invest for terms longer than 12 months without prior approval of the minister of
finance;  and  (iii)  an  amendment  to  allow  members  to  withdraw  their  account  balance  at
retirement in one lump sum from age 55, as well as allowing withdrawal prior to this age under
certain circumstances.
17. NPF has about 25,000 active members (members who have made a contribution in the
last 30 days) out of a potential workforce of 50,000-60,000. Members and their employers
contribute 5 percent of salary. At age 55, members can take either a lump sum or a pension.
Until December 1998 they could only take a pension. Now virtually everybody takes the lump
sum. The reason for offering a lump sum was (i) the pension was very small as most members
had balances between ST10-ST30,000, and (ii) the members wanted a lump sum to start a
small business; however there is no evidence that the lump sum is being used for this purpose.
18. Less than 5 percent of NPF’s investments are in equity. This is so small because there
is no secondary market and no price transparency. NPF currently has investments in two
companies, both of which were recommended by South Pacific Project Facility (SPPF). At
present,  equity  investment  in  NPF,  are  essentially  locked  in.  As  of  December  1997,

ST11 million. Although NPF recently obtained permission to invest up to 10 percent of its
portfolio overseas, no foreign investments have been made. ANZ has been trying to set up a
regional meeting in Melbourne so that provident funds in the region can work together to
establish an overseas fund.
19. The strengthening of NPF has been part of financial sector reforms in Samoa. As part of
these reforms, NPF has undertaken a major reorganization and continued its strong growth, a
corporate plan has been developed, and an actuarial review is now ongoing. NPF has moved to
implement a market-based interest rate policy for loans to its members. Prior to the reforms

1. Demand for Microfinance in Samoa
25. The  growth  in  demand  for  microfinance  services,  especially  for  informal  financial
services is an indication of the unmet demand for financial services, especially by low-income
households and people in rural areas who have limited access to formal financial services.
Demand for microfinance services is increasing in Samoa as a result of vulnerability to poverty,
unemployment and the burgeoning informal sector, and lack of access by the poor to formal
financial services.
26. In Samoa, as in many countries in the Pacific, poverty remains a sensitive issue. It is
believed that one never goes without in Samoa because of the fa’asamoa, which is a kind of a
safety net that protects and provides for all members of an extended network of family and
friends. However, this support system is now being threatened by the transition from traditional
to modern society. Evidence indicates that social systems are being undermined in these
transitional times as seen by increased crime rates, rising incidence of family disputes and
marriage breakups, and emergence of relative poverty. The 1998 Samoa household income
and expenditure survey found that one in three households could not properly meet their basic
needs and, therefore, were poor relative to standards of living in Samoa.
27. Unemployment is on the rise in Samoa. Private sector employment has been in decline
falling by 0.56 percent and 1.26 percent in 1997 and 1998 respectively (Data from National
Provident Fund). The situation in not likely to improve over the foreseeable future. The waged
sector will not expand at a sufficient rate to provide jobs to meet present demands of the more
than 4,000 annual school leavers, and those that will be affected by reforms in the public sector.
The people in informal employment increased from 27,400 in 1986 to 29,000 in 1991; while
those working in the formal sector were 45,500 in 1986 increasing to 47,900 in 1991. Estimates
are that the urban informal market has grown by around 10 percent annually, and involves 500-
600 households. Women, in particularly, are more actively involved in informal sector activities
to  augment  the  family  income.  Approximately  90  percent  of  women  traders  at  the  food,
handicraft, and flea markets are women.
2. Supply of Microfinance
28. The  few  providers  of  microfinance  services  in  Samoa  include  nongovernment

scheme with funding provided by UNDP but on a very limited scale. Other NGOs have already
signified interest in microfinance, but there is no legal framework allowing NGOs to engage in

savings. NGOs, including WIBF, need institutional strengthening, in terms of TA and training, to
be able to effectively expand their outreach and to achieve operational self-sufficiency in the

29. The longstanding providers of microfinance services in Samoa are the credit unions who

SAMOA VENTURE CAPITAL FUND
A. Background
1. The proposal for a venture capital facility (VCF) in Samoa arose as a result of the South
Pacific Project Facility (SPPF) aid review undertaken in November 1998 of the International
Finance Corporation (IFC)/Admiralty Study on Pacific Islands Financing Needs 1998. The study
identified some generally available VCFs in the region from sources including Pacific Island
Investment Facility (PIIF) (IFC), and the Papua New Guinea/Fiji Islands based Kula Fund.
However, the former has a minimum investment limit of $100,000, and the latter also supports
larger projects and had until recently confined itself to Melanesia. Other funding sources such
as New Zealand’s Pacific Island Investment Development Scheme (PIIDS) have constraints
relating to participation by aid country nationals.
2. A  clear  gap  exists  for  financing  below  ST300,000  for  locally  based  projects.  In
consultation with SPPF, the Government of Samoa expressed a keen interest in piloting a VCF
that operates in this lower range. As a result, an indicative feasibility study was commissioned
by SPPF (Review of Feasibility) and extensive market research completed. The final step in the
process was the development of an investment memorandum for submission to the proposed
subscribers: (i) IFC; (ii) Asian Development Bank (ADB), (iii) Australia New Zealand Bank
(ANZ), (iv) Development Bank of Samoa (DBS), and (v) Samoa National Provident Fund (NPF).
B. Structure of Facility and Return on Investment
3. The recommended structure is a 100 percent equity financed facility, investing by way of
a range of equity and quasi-equity instruments with the preferred instrument being venture
capital loans. The internal rate of return (IRR) for this structure is 8.6 percent, which is below is
expected  in  more  mature  markets,  but  this  is  partly  attributable  to  (i)  very  conservative
assumptions about the earnings of the typical investee company, (ii) delayed returns while the
investee overcomes initial losses, and (iii) high provisions for losses on equity investments.
Logically, a true VCF is preferably financed from equity. For Samoa, the proposed VCF will fund
expansion projects, at a somewhat lower risk than true venture capital, and therefore some level
of gearing is acceptable and lower loan losses are more realistic.
4. With VCF investments likely to be primarily in established businesses, projected loan
losses should be significantly less than might be the case with mainly seed capital or true
venture investments. However, for the purpose of the model, a very conservative 25 percent
loan loss provision has been allowed for on the outstanding portfolio. This produces revenue
losses from year 1, which may be too conservative an assumption when calculating the IRR, but
is a prudent safety factor. A typical investee company forecast has been prepared based on a
conservative, agricultural model, paying interest at 20 percent per annum on its venture capital
loan.

SUMMARY SOCIAL ASSESSMEMT
A. Context
1. The social assessment analyzed information on social patterns that have a bearing on
target  group  preferences  and  constraints  in  the  context  of  the  proposed  Small  Business
Development Project.  Data used originate from the interviews conducted during the course of
the  project  preparatory  technical  assistance  (TA)  and  from  a  few  other  sources,  mostly
ethnological and anthropological studies and consolidated documents of assistance agencies
such as Australian Agency for International Development and the World Bank.
2. Samoa is a relatively compact archipelagic group, consisting of two main islands—Upolu
and Savai'i, and five smaller islands, with land area covering a total of 2,820 square kilometres
2 2
(km ), and an exclusive economic zone of 120,000 km .  Samoa belongs to the Polynesian part
of the Pacific, together with Cook Islands, Tonga, and French Polynesia.
3. The country is relatively mountainous, with about 40 percent of Upolu and 50 percent of
Savaii characterized by steep slopes descending from volcanic crests. The physically compact
nature of the country makes it very easy for communities to communicate with each other, in
sharp contrast to islands in Melanesia, which stretch over thousands of kilometres of sea.
4. The two main islands are serviced by good road infrastructure, and daily ferry and air
services connect the two islands.
5. The urban rural divide is relatively unpronounced on the main island of Upolu. Daily
commuting into Apia for work, particularly from villages in northwest Upolu, means that a
substantial number of the population interchange daily between urban and rural life. Increasing
urbanization is causing a shift in family patterns. The concept of the extended family as an
operational unit becomes less prominent as they move from rural to urban areas. However,
extended families still feature significantly in terms of collective support to meet obligations on a
larger scale.
6. The urban drift, coupled with continuing losses from out-migration has led to a shortage
of labor for agricultural activities and support for communal village-based activities.
7. Agricultural production remains the main source of livelihood security for almost 70
percent of the population, with the smallholder family producing goods for household needs, for
sale, and for use in customary exchanges.  Formal employment in registered businesses was
7,643 as of March 2000, excluding the Yazaki factory. Most paid employment opportunities are
in the Apia urban area. Remittances from overseas continue to be a major source of cash
income within the family household.
8. Over 80 percent of all land is customary land, which is under traditional matai control.
The land provides the major source of income for nearly 70 percent of the economically active
population. Alienation of customary land is prohibited by law (land cannot be transferred or
made freehold), although lease arrangements are possible.
9. Samoans generally are well integrated into the cash economy. Most households have
family overseas who send regular remittances. In many cases, this is the only major source of
cash  income  other  than  the  sale  of  surplus  produce.  Although  women  are  the  traditional

producers of handicraft, the men more often obtain the income from the proceeds of any sale.
Women are the savers, while men control and determine the distribution of the household
income.
10. Social Organization. Samoans live in villages, made up of the local members of a
number of ‘aiga, usually beteen 20 and 40, with each ‘aiga headed by a matai who is effectively
the head of the family, managing its lands and house sites, allocating labor and other resources,
and representing the group in the village council, or fono. The traditional Samoan village is
organized according to matai, the aualuma (daughters of the village), faletua and tausi (wives of
the matai), and aumaga (untitled men). Authority, defence, and the production of food are the
responsibilities of the men, while moral authority, ceremony, hospitality, and the production of
exchange valuables are the work of women.
11. The Pulenu’u (village mayor) is the official link between the government and the village.
Each village elects a representative to the Pulenu’u committee for a three-year term. The final
decision whether to accept or reject proposed development programs rests with the village
councils.
12. Villages operate as semiautonomous polities under the leadership of the council of
chiefs, and the womens committee. Every family is represented on these two bodies. The
village council decides issues affecting village law and order, land issue and use, and food
security. Their decisions are binding, and sanctions can be harsh.
13. The  adoption  of  Christianity  in  the  nineteenth  century  brought  about  fundamental
changes to Samoan life and ideals. Villages become congregations through a covenant dividing
local governance between the secular realm controlled by the matai councils, and the religious
realm, presided over by resident pastors.  The arrangement persists in every Samoan village to
today.
14. Pastors are highly honored and respected, but the relationship between a pastor and a
village sets the pastor apart from other leaders. The pastor has authority over church affairs but
no formal say in the secular affairs of a village. It is part of the covenant, that pastors may not
take matai titles.
15. Pastors are called by village congregations, which the pastor's family with a house, gifts
of food, a money income, lands for planting, etc. The money income comes from regular
donations from the congregation, which are publicly announced. Thus a very strong element of
competition between the various aiga of a congregation exists, the outcome of which can affect
the status of the aiga  both in the church and the village life.
16. Besides supporting the pastor (and family), the congregations also build and maintain
their  own  churches  and  other  facilities  such  as  meeting  places.  Churches  are  generally
elaborate and the largest of structures in the rural area. Funds are raised through special levies
on the matai of a congregation, including those living overseas, and through organized parties
traveling to the migrant communities in New Zealand.
17. Most churches open with a substantial debt burden as church loans are commonly
favored over enterprise loans because of the good repayment record. The key to repayment is
the ceremonial church opening, which draw large crowds, the village as a whole and church
members from other villages, all bear contributions.

18. Thus,  these  social  and  traditional  practices  influence  the  control  of  resources  and
economic  decision  making  at  the  household  level.  The  land  tenure  system  and  social
considerations, as related to credit, savings, and enterprise development, are taken from the
general context and analyzed in greater detail. The final part of the social analysis lists the
major issues and options related to social analysis.
B. Land Tenure
19. Some 80 percent of the land in Samoa is held under customary tenure, being divided
among descent groups known as aiga, each of which is headed by a matai or chief, chosen by
the members of the aiga. The alienation of customary land is prohibited by law (land cannot be
transferred or made freehold), although lease arrangements are possible.
20. The Land and Titles Court is one of the fundamental institutions of the Samoan social
and political life. The origin of the court lies in the 1889 Berlin Treaty’s prohibition of the sale of
the  customary  land  outside  of  Apia  boundaries.  It  also  established  a  land  commission  to
investigate claims. The Land and Titles court established in 1903 continued the policy regarding
alienation of customary land, and took on responsibility for adjudicating rival Samoan claims to
land and matai titles.
21. Under New Zealand administration, the prohibitions were further endorsed, and the 1962
Constitution  laid  the  legal  framework  for  the  present  situation  whereby  land  is  held  “in
accordance with Samoan custom and usage and the law relating to Samoan custom and
usage.” The currently relevant law is the Land and Titles Court Act of 1981, which provides that,
in all matters brought before it, the court will apply (i) customs and usage, and (ii) the law
relating to customs and usage.
22. The Court’s jurisdiction is exercised by a President and at least two Samoan judges and
two Samoan assessors; no less than four are on the bench for any court hearing. There are no
written or oral opinions, which might constitute a body of legal precedent. Each case is decided
“on its own merits,” having regard for both general opinion and acceptable local variations to
custom.
23. There is some evidence that on-the-ground village practices have for some time been
diverging from what the court would regard as proper custom. There has been a considerable
degree of individualization, with people also being allowed to pass on lands to their immediate
children, without any rights to dispose of the land through sale.
24.  No transition freeholding of customary land is implied by the changes, although the
situation is further confused by the process of title-splitting and the creation of new titles for
voting purposes, which has been ongoing at the same time as the alleged “individualization” that
is taking place.
25. The most recent Agricultural Survey (1993) identified that over 25 percent of agricultural
households controlled less than the two hectares considered to be the minimum amount of land
a household would require access to, if they were to derive their total livelihood from agriculture.
The Apia Urban Youth Survey (1995) showed that 32 percent of youth felt that agriculture was a
way to improve their economic life but access to land was a constraint.
26. In summary, customary land tenure in Samoa is tied into the social organization of
Samoans. The alienation of customary land is, and will remain, a challenging issue to tackle, as

land is the source of family identify and security. Although leasing of customary land is possible,
the financial Institutions reluctance to accept land leases as security has an impact on access to
credit.  Long-term  security  of  tenure  is  an  essential  precondition  to  extensive  agricultural
development, which features a heavy investment in fixed assets.  With a continuing rural urban
migration drift, there is increased pressure for land. Demand for land is leading to the loss of an
estimated  900  hectares  of  forest  annually  to  land  clearance  for  gardens  and  commercial
plantations, leading to the degradation of watersheds, and increased run offs. The family matai
allocates land to ensure that all members share the good as well as the poorer quality land, so
land holding usually consists of a number of small parcels, not always contiguous. The division
of such land, and the physical distance at times from the village, creates problems in working
the land economically.
C. Role of Women
27. Although women have no say in land allocation, or the village law and order, they
nevertheless hold a strong and effective position of informal power within the village affairs.
Women are considered the dominant influence in terms of village development. The women’s
committee provides the energy, drive, and staying power that often sees a village project
through to fruition.
28. In the village ceremonial affairs, there is a clear distinction between the unmarried
women (usually young and born in the village), who together make up the aualuma, and those
who have married in, who are collectively known as faletua ma tausi. As “sisters” to the men of
the  village,  the  aualuma  have  some  status,  as  shown  by  the  part  they  play  in  the  kava
presentations, which mark formal intervillage gatherings. The in marrying “wives” have a much
lesser formal status on such occasions, and are considered subservient to their husbands.
29. Both categories of women join the village women’s committee, which is run by its own
council, with each woman filling a ranked position according to the rank of her husband.
30. In addition to their family and household chores, women also engage in other income
earning activities to supplement the family income. In the 20-29 year age group, an average of
9.8 hours per week1 is devoted to the production of handicrafts, which subsequently are used as
ceremonial gifts or sold for cash.
31. Women are the majority of informal traders. A visit to the vegetable market at Fugaleii
and the handicraft market confirms women operate the majority of stalls. However, the control of
the income clearly lies with the male of the household.
32. The labor economy and division of labor within the household resembles at other areas
of Polynesia. The men of the household take prime responsibility for undertaking household
agriculture, farming, and fishing, while the female devotes her time to cooking, washing, looking
after children, and handicraft production. Women do not provide substantial inputs into the
production of agricultural crops or produce, although the contribution of women and children to
the small family units is becoming more significant with the labor shortage. The women are
responsible for managing the family budget relative to the payment of school fees, etc.

D. Village Business Enterprises
34. Pisinisi, the Samoan word for business, has been an established part of most villages
since the beginning of the century, when retail stores were set up, which also acted as buyers of
copra for urban interests. In more recent years, they have been joined by bus operators, taxis,
and small beach fale enterprises aimed at the domestic and international lower-priced tourist
market.
35. Pisinisi carries prestige, distinguishing a person from other villagers, who are generally
pleased to make use of the services provided. Credit sales is an ever-present risk, and is a
major cause of business failure within the rural sector. Field work carried out during the TA
identified that although a village-based business might collapse as a result of credit not being
repaid, the members of the village who brought about the collapse through not repaying, felt no
shame, while the entrepreneur whose business failed often felt acutely embarrassed, with
several examples being cited where the entrepreneur left the village completely.
36. There is an expectation that village businesses will contribute generously to village
activities,  with  the  villagers  reciprocating  through  increased  loyalty  and  support  for  the
entrepreneur. Such success can be readily converted into worthwhile matai titles.
37. The long-term ambition of such businessmen is to become a member of Parliament for
their district, cashing in the obligations, loyalties, and trust they have built up over the years.
38. A  lack  of  exposure  to  new  ideas  has  led  to  a  copy  cat  mentality  among  rural
entrepreneurs, as evidenced by the number of small retail food stores that can sometimes be
found in one single village of 300-400 people. The four essential elements for microenterprise
development  are  access  to  finance,  markets,  management,  and  technical  training.  A
diversification  of  the  economic  activities  at  the  village  level  is  an  essential  element  for
developing this sector.
39. Remittances in cash and in kind from overseas are often a high component of total
incomes received in rural households. The 1998 household income and expenditure survey
identified, on a national basis, in excess of 12 percent of all household income comes from
overseas remittances. This component of total income is highest on the island of Savai'i, where
19.4 percent of total income is derived from overseas. The Women in Business Foundation
identify this as a specific disincentive at the village level for starting microenterprises. Within a
national context, remittances are expected to maintain their long-term growth trend rate of
around 3 percent in 2000.

40. Within the Samoan culture, it is rare for an individual to accumulate wealth. Instead,
people are expected to give money, goods, and services to meet the social obligations of their
families through fa’alavelave. The family matai is responsible for distributing these items on
behalf of the family. Obligations under fa’alavelave can be demanding and immediate, often
requiring families to contribute to the costs of funerals and weddings at very short notice.

Ignoring these responsibilities can result in being ostracized within the family and cut off socially
from the village.
41. Negative  saving  has  prevailed  since  1985,  largely  the  result  of  high  levels  of
consumption induced by substantial inflows of personal remittances from overseas. Previous
studies have concluded that “Samoans do not save,” although this needs to be considered in
the context of social and cultural obligations imposed through fa’alavelave.
42. Fa’alavelale does represent a form of obligation on the part of the party receiving the
benefits of fa’alavelave to reciprocate in kind at some yet to be determined time in the future.

expanding their clientele.
